page.lettertext:
fol.394r
A l
re
to
M
r
Thomas Bodley
Whereas the
Estates generall
of the
United
provinces
have written of late a verie sharpe and soure l
re
, to
her Ma
tie
and us
against
S
r
Edward Norreys
governo
r
of
Ostend
charging him w
th
taking (of
his owne aucthoritie) their contribuc
o
ns, and that he doth dispose at his pleasure
of those publick Revenues, and graunt licences and saveguardes to the villages
towardes
Flandres
whereby of his privat aucthoritie, he douth rayse contribuc
o
n
and doth furnish the Enemy by that meanes of victuels Likewise he dothe
disobaie the Comaundement
of the said Estates, of whom he receaved the
goverment of the said Towne being there unto bound by oath and therefore
the doe require speedie Redresse of these thinges, otherwise they doe
test &
signifie their minde and porpose to remove him from that Charge and go
v
m
t
Although S
r
Edward Norries:/ havyng some intelligence of their Conceaved
displeasure afore hand, and of late also having receaved like sharpe l
re
s from the
States hath by his l
re
s assured us of the untruthe of this Charge and
accusacon, and for his better excuse and Justifieng hath sent unto them from
Ostend
a Comyssiary of their owne to satisfie them in all those pointes,
Nev
r
thes her Ma
t
pleasure is (for the further Justificac
o
n and clearing of
the gent that yo
u
shall lett the States generall understand of his avowinge
that these are untruthe where w
th
he is charged and that those Contribucons
w
ch
S
r
Edward is charged to have receaved came not to his owne handes
But being such as were appointed for the fortefieng of the Towne, and
maintenance of necessarie re
acons of
e breaches against the sea were
receaved by suche as are appointed Office
rs
for that purpose: and employed
by their discretions to so needfull ause. And where they finde them selves
agreaved that he hath not sent suche Companies unto them as they have requi-
red, he could not
forme their request at the tyme required putting the Towne
in daunger being aplace that was greately threatened by the Enemy and yet
he hath retorned such as was extraordinarilie of late sent to him when he feared
the accesse of the Enemy Therefor if the shall not rest satisfied w
th
the
aunsweres of S
r
Edward Norries now at the Coming of the said Comissarie yo
u
maie move them (for the better manifestac
o
n of those matte
rs
) to send some
one appointed by them, w
th
whom m
r
Gilpin maie also be sent (as directed
from thence) and they two together maie examine indifferently and
ticulerly
those matters where w
th
S
r
Edward standeth charged, uppon whose reporte
we hope the estates shalbe so satisfied w
th
the
ceeading of the gen
t
, that
they will continew that wonted favo
r
and good will towards him w
ch
hither
to they have: borne unto him And because yo
u
maie be the better hable to
aunswere all the objections, and matters they have to charge him w
th
all, yo
u
shall by vertue hereof send to S
r
Edward Norris to be
ticulerly enformed
of him of all those pointes w
h
we leave to yo
r
discreation so to handele
this matter, as maie best
s
rve for the furtherance of her Ma
t
s
rvice, and
clearing of the gent being not unknowne unto yo
u
that this their conceaved
displeasure and quarill doth spring from some other Roote as we doubt not
but yo
u
can well diserne that the
states of Zealande
are very loath , to
see the Towne of Ostend to grow to any assurance; to have trade either
of fishing or other otherwise in marchandise./
